abstract: pmc Clin Epigenetics Clin Epigenetics 1699 clinepig Clinical Epigenetics 1868-7075 1868-7083 BMC PMC12481779 PMC12481779.1 12481779 12481779 41024270 10.1186/s13148-025-01978-x 1978 1 Review The OGG1 Ser326Cys polymorphism: molecular mechanisms of disease susceptibility and precision medicine applications Wang XueJian Li Bo Gao JingYa Wang Kun wangk696@qdu.edu.cn Yang SuMin SMinYangFY@126.com https://ror.org/021cj6z65 grid.410645.2 0000 0001 0455 0905 Department of Cardiovascular Surgery, Institute of Chronic Diseases, The Affiliated Hospital of Qingdao University, College of Medicine, Qingdao University, 29 9 2025 2025 17 478173 153 8 7 2025 7 9 2025 29 09 2025 01 10 2025 01 10 2025 © The Author(s) 2025 2025 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ Open Access http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ DNA molecules are susceptible to reactive oxygen species (ROS) attack leading to oxidative damage, of which 8-oxoguanine (8-oxoG) is a core oxidative marker. OGG1 acts as a DNA repair enzyme and maintains genomic stability by specifically repairing 8-oxoG through the base excision repair (BER) pathway. The Ser326Cys polymorphism significantly reduces enzyme activity and potentially impacts phosphorylation-mediated subcellular localization dynamics and epigenetic regulatory networks, thereby potentially exacerbating genomic instability. In this review, we analyzed the association between the OGG1 Ser326Cys polymorphism and different diseases, such as risk, platinum-based chemotherapy sensitivity, and radiotherapy toxicity in cancer. In neurodegenerative disorders, the Cys326 type leads to the accumulation of 8-oxoG in neurons and accelerates CAG triplet repeat amplification. In metabolic disorders, its insufficient repair may trigger β-cell dysfunction, which increases the risk of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Finally, we integrated multiomics data and proposed a genotype-based precision intervention strategy to provide a theoretical basis for disease risk prediction, personalized therapy, and novel targeted drug development. The 8-oxoG repair activity of OGG1 containing Ser326 (C) is sevenfold higher than that of OGG1 containing Cys326 (G) [ 4 5 6 5 7 8 9 10 Polymorphisms of OGG1 gene are closely related to human diseases, and the study of OGG1 gene polymorphisms can lead to a better understanding of the mechanisms of diseases, thus providing new ideas and methods for the diagnosis, treatment as well as prevention of diseases. For example, the repair capacity caused by OGG1 gene polymorphism can be compensated by using OGG1 agonists [ 11 Structure and function of the OGG1 gene Although the role of polymorphisms in OGG1 in disease has received widespread attention, the molecular basis of its functional differences still needs to be systematically analyzed. hOGG1’s unique structural features and dynamic repair mechanisms provide key entry points for understanding the pathological effects caused by polymorphisms. hOGG1 is located in the 3p25 region of the chromosome and consists of eight exons, with the start codon (ATG) and the stop codon (TAG) sequences located in exons 1 and 7, respectively [ 2 12 2 13 14 Under normal physiological conditions, when binding to the target DNA, both of them have high activity and can repair damaged DNA through the mechanism of BER, which is as follows: OGG1 slides down the DNA double-stranded helix, and when it recognizes the 8-oxoG in the process of sliding, it will reduce the sliding speed, and then it will extend the amino acid probe and insert it into DNA double-stranded chain, so that the DNA backbone is twisted by nearly 70°. Under the force of this distortion, the damaged nucleotide is pushed out from the interior of the DNA helix. Then, the base pair is placed in the active site pocket of OGG1. This process is metaphorically described as “pinch, push, pull, and insert.” The Cys326 mutation may disrupt this kinetic process due to a phosphorylation disorder [ 15 16 1 Fig. 1 The effects of 8-oxoG and OGG1 on DNA repair. Oxidative stress causes DNA damage and 8-oxoG is the final oxidation product. Since 8-oxoG differs from normal guanine in that C8 contains oxygen rather than hydrogen and N7 is hydrogen rather than an electron pair, it leads to differences in replication, from C:8-OXOG to 8-OXOG:A to A:T. Upon recognition, OGG1 triggers a bend in the DNA that extrudes the damaged nucleotide from the inside of the DNA helix, and then puts a base pair in the pocket of the OGG1 active site. The base pair is then placed into the pocket of the OGG1 active site. OGG1 then cuts the base, which is repaired by APE1 to form a hydroxyl group, and subsequently restores the site to correct alignment by DNA polymerase and ligase Remarkably, the DNA repair protein OGG1 plays a dual function in maintaining genomic stability: It not only relies on its classical base excision activity, but also influences genomic stability through a dynamic epigenetic regulatory network. This repair-epigenetic coupling mechanism provides a novel perspective for understanding the pathogenic effects of polymorphisms [ 17 18 23 13 24 26 27 At the chromatin level, the repair efficacy of OGG1 is itself finely regulated by epigenetic modifications: Acetylation modifications such as histone H3K9ac and H4K16ac promote the proximity of OGG1 to the damage site by relaxing the chromatin structure, which can enhance the recognition efficiency of OGG1 for 8-oxoG. CDK4-mediated phosphorylation of Ser326 leads to an increase in its 8-oxoG resection activity, while c-Abl-mediated phosphorylation of Tyr122 limited its function through nucleoplasmic shuttling [ 28 29 30 Association of OGG1 gene polymorphisms with disease As mentioned earlier, the OGG1 Ser326Cys polymorphism results in a significant reduction in the 8-oxoG repair activity of the protein encoded by the Cys326 allele. The clinical significance of this defect in intrinsic DNA repair capacity lies in its strong gene–environment interaction with diverse environmental exposure factors. These environmental factors include both exogenous exposures (such as tobacco smoke dietary components [e.g., red meat, vegetables, alcohol], carcinogens, and therapeutic drugs [e.g., platinum-based chemotherapy]) and endogenous states. The OGG1 Ser326Cys polymorphism profoundly modulates individual susceptibility to and disease progression of multiple conditions: When exposed to synergistic risk factors, Cys326 carriers (especially homozygotes) exhibit significantly amplified risks of cancers (such as lung cancer, colorectal cancer, and breast cancer), neurodegenerative diseases (such as Huntington's disease), type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, male infertility, and autoimmune diseases are significantly amplified; under specific treatment contexts (such as platinum-based chemotherapy), this polymorphism may also influence tumor cell sensitivity and treatment-related toxicity]. Similarly, in breast cancer, where estrogen metabolism is active, this repair defect synergistically amplifies with hormone-driven oxidative stress. Breast cancer, one of the most prevalent types of cancer in women worldwide and the second leading cause of cancer-related deaths [ 46 47 34 48 49 2 Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) characterized by negative expression of estrogen receptor (ER), progesterone receptor (PR), and human epidermal growth factor (HER-2) [ 50 47 51 52 53 Colorectal cancer The pathogenesis of colorectal cancer (CRC) is complex, involving multiple aspects of race, environmental factors, and interactions between genes and the environment [ 54 39 35 31 In terms of treatment, most patients are diagnosed with locally advanced disease, and multimodal therapy combining radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and surgery has become the standard of care for such patients. Especially for resectable tumors in the middle and lower third of the rectum, neoadjuvant radiotherapy or radiochemotherapy plus total mesenteric excision (TME) has become the standard of care [ 55 56 2 57 58 Liver cancer It has been found that the OGG1 Ser326Cys polymorphism is not strongly associated with some cancers. For example, in hepatocellular carcinoma, the Cys326 genotype in OGG1 Ser326Cys was found to have a high recurrence rate and a low survival rate. A significant dose effect on the risk of hepatocellular carcinoma in carriers of the Cys326 allele was shown by a case-control study in a Chinese population [ 24 2 28 Prostate cancer Further, prostate cancer (PC) is one of the leading causes of death in the West, and DNA repair defects increase the risk of oncogenic DNA damage events, playing a role in the age-related increase in PC risk [ 59 4 60 61 63 Neurodegenerative disease In addition to malignant tumors, the effects of OGG1 polymorphisms on genomic stability are also evident in terminally differentiated cells. Accumulated 8-oxoG damage in neurons triggers a vicious cycle of neurodegeneration due to reduced repair efficiency. Huntington's chorea (HD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disease that leads to cognitive impairment, choreiform movements, and death, usually occurring 15–20 years after the onset of symptoms. In normal populations, the number of CAG repeats remains below 35, whereas in patients with HD, the number of CAG repeats ranges from 35 to more than 100, resulting in amplification of polyglutamine fragments in the protein [ 64 65 36 4 65 Fig. 4 OGG1Ser326Cys association with neurodegenerative diseases and diabetes. Oxidative damage accumulates in the brain tissue of AD patients, which may contribute to an individual's susceptibility to disease or disease progression [ 66 67 67 68 Diabetes Diabetes is a chronic disease that occurs when the pancreas does not produce enough insulin or the body is unable to effectively utilize the insulin it produces [ 69 70 71 8 4 72 73 In general, when insulin resistance is increased, a compensatory increase in insulin secretion occurs at the same time to maintain plasma glucose levels within the normal range. In subjects genotyped Ser/Ser, insulin resistance is increased in gastrointestinal subjects assessed by HOMA-α and insulin secretion appears to increase as expected when assessed by HOMA-β. However, in subjects with genotype Ser/Cys + Cys/Cys, HOMA-β was decreased in GI subjects although HOMA-α was also increased [ 8 40 4 Cardiovascular disease Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is a term used to describe many heart diseases. It can refer to several conditions: coronary heart disease (CHD), peripheral arterial disease, cerebrovascular disease, rheumatic and congenital heart disease, and venous thromboembolism [ 74 75 76 32 77 32 Infertility Differences in Ser326 and Cys326 DNA repair activity also have implications for sperm quality. Infertility is a common reproductive disorder, with male factor accounting for 40–50% of all infertility cases [ 78 5 79 Autoimmune diseases Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic autoimmune disease that can lead to deformities and severe disability due to irreversible damage to tendons, joints, and bones [ 80 81 82 Gene–environment Interactions The interaction between the OGG1 Ser326Cys polymorphism and environmental exposure significantly amplifies disease risk, and this effect is genotype-specific. Numerous studies have shown that individuals carrying the Cys allele with reduced repair activity (particularly Cys/Cys homozygotes) are more sensitive to oxidative damage induced by specific environmental factors, and their disease risk significantly increases upon exposure [ 5 At the level of carcinogen exposure, the Cys326/Cys326 genotype synergistically drives genomic instability with smoking: The Cys genotype reduces OGG1 repair function, while smoking induces ROS production, and the two synergistically lead to the accumulation of 8-OHdG. Studies have shown that among heavy smokers, the risk of infertility in individuals carrying the Cys allele (Ser/Cys + Cys/Cys) is 2.32 times higher than in the wild-type Ser/Ser genotype, significantly higher than in moderate smokers (1.75 times), suggesting that the higher the smoking dose, the stronger the harmful effects of the genotype [ 5 P 35 Dietary factors exhibit bidirectional regulatory effects: High red meat intake (> 500 g/week) increases CRC risk by 1.8-fold in European populations through heme iron-mediated colonic lumen·OH radical bursts [ 31 P P 32 10 Other important polymorphisms of the OGG1 gene Ser326Cys is currently the most extensively studied and relatively well-documented OGG1 gene locus. However, research indicates that the OGG1 gene exhibits widespread genetic variation. This enhances hOGG1's repair efficiency and reduces the accumulation of oxidative DNA damage Potential applications of OGG1 gene polymorphisms in disease prevention and treatment Prevention The OGG1 Ser326Cys polymorphism plays an important role in the onset and progression of various diseases [ 88 89 90 91 5 Fig. 5 Strategies of OGG1 gene polymorphism in disease prevention and treatment. OGG1 Ser326Cys gene polymorphism is a high-risk disease biomarker, and its pathogenicity, together with environmental exposures such as smoking and alcohol consumption and population genetic background, constitutes a multifactorial risk system. For patients with the Cys/Cys genotype, clinical preference can be given to antiangiogenic drugs or immune checkpoint inhibitors, followed by precision editing of the OGG1 gene or screening of chemo-sensitivity regulatory genes in combination with CRISPR technology and targeted sgRNA design. Single-cell sequencing can resolve the expression differences and functional heterogeneity of this polymorphism at the cellular level For example, using the median hOGG1 expression level (3.61) as a cutoff, patients were divided into a high-expression group (≥ 3.61) and a low-expression group (< 3.61): The 1-year, 2-year, and 3-year survival rates (87.91%, 70.33%, and 63.74%) in the low-expression group were significantly higher than those in the high-expression group (79.12%, 56.04%, and 43.96%, P 92 Given that OGG1 polymorphisms (particularly Ser326Cys) have been shown to have potential as cancer risk predictors and are not independent carcinogenic factors but rather amplify disease risk through significant interactive effects with specific environmental exposures (such as smoking, occupational pesticide/nicotine exposure). This makes it an ideal target for risk stratification and precision prevention. Identifying high-risk populations (such as smokers and those with specific occupational exposures) and conducting OGG1 genotyping is the first step in implementing precision strategies [ 93 P P 93 p 93 To more accurately identify individuals at highest risk due to gene–environment interactions, it is necessary to integrate OGG1 genotypes with other risk factors (such as ethnicity and age) to construct a comprehensive risk prediction model. For example, OGG1 polymorphisms (GG vs. CC genotypes) may simultaneously increase cancer risk in Asian (OR ≈ 1.56) and Caucasian populations (OR ≈ 1.40), but the strength of this effect varies by ethnicity; age itself is also a significant risk factor (OR 1.12, P P 6 5 Mature and reliable OGG1 gene polymorphism detection techniques (such as PCR-RFLP, gene sequencing) can accurately locate the polymorphic sites and provide a basis for identifying high-risk individuals [ 93 94 95 P 96 5 Treatment Based on the efficacy of the aforementioned biomarkers, targeted therapeutic strategies targeting OGG1 polymorphisms have become an inevitable choice. CRISPR technology provides a powerful tool for validating the functional mechanisms of OGG1 polymorphisms in preclinical models, thereby advancing our understanding of OGG1 polymorphisms and laying the groundwork for designing therapeutic interventions. By designing targeted sgRNA (small guide RNA) combined with homologous directed repair (HDR) templates, precise editing of the OGG1 Ser326Cys site can be achieved, confirming that Cys326 leads to reduced 8-oxoG repair efficiency and increased genomic instability [ 89 97 98 99 100 5 Based on the identification of therapeutic targets, integrating genotype information into clinical decision-making has become a key challenge. By constructing multiomics-driven models, precision treatment for patients can be achieved. Single-cell multiomics reveal expression differences and functional heterogeneity of OGG1 gene polymorphisms across different cell types. In lung cancer tissues, OGG1-Cys326 activates oxidative damage genes (HMOX1/NQO1) in lung cancer alveolar epithelial cells and promotes inflammation (NF-κB) in immune cell [ 101 102 103 89 104 105 5 Based on the aforementioned multiomics technology, the most suitable treatment methods are formulated for patients based on their genes, environment, and lifestyle. For patients carrying specific OGG1 gene polymorphisms, selecting appropriate drugs and dosages can effectively reduce the incidence of drug toxicity and side effects and improve the effectiveness of drug treatment. For example, OGG1 polymorphisms influence chemotherapy sensitivity. Platinum-based drugs (such as cisplatin and carboplatin) exert their antitumor effects by inducing interstrand crosslinks in DNA, which destabilize the DNA double helix, block replication, and inhibit transcription. Defects in OGG1 function may enhance tumor cell sensitivity to platinum-based drugs [ 106 Su et al. studied 610 patients with primary NSCLC (median age 60.3 years) and found that patients carrying the variant G allele (CG + GG genotype) had significantly poorer overall survival (OS) (unadjusted HR 1.57, 95% CI 1.05–2.35, P 103 P P 33 P P 33 Based on the aforementioned mechanisms and clinical evidence, the following precision intervention strategies targeting the OGG1 Ser326Cys polymorphism can be developed: For patients carrying the Cys allele: Due to their relatively weaker DNA repair capacity, they are more sensitive to DNA damage induced by platinum-based drugs and are expected to have a higher treatment response rate and longer PFS (such as longer PFS in the CC genotype in Yu's study), with a lower risk of gastrointestinal toxicity. Prioritize platinum-based combination chemotherapy regimens (such as cisplatin combined with pemetrexed). Given their higher sensitivity, consider appropriately reducing the dose of platinum-based drugs to maintain efficacy while further reducing the risk of cumulative toxicity. For patients with the CC genotype: Due to their stronger DNA repair capacity, they may have relatively lower sensitivity to platinum monotherapy, with shorter expected PFS (such as shorter PFS in the CG genotype in the Yu study), and may require more intensive treatment regimens to achieve optimal outcomes. To overcome their strong repair capacity, it may be necessary to increase the intensity of platinum-based drug doses (within tolerable limits). Additionally, consideration should be given to combining with other DNA-damaging agents with synergistic mechanisms of action, such as the antimetabolite gemcitabine (by inhibiting DNA synthesis and enhancing the formation of platinum-DNA adducts) or taxane agents (by stabilizing microtubules), to maximize DNA damage effects and improve efficacy [ 103 107 108 Within the framework of precision therapy based on the OGG1 genotype, implementing dynamic dose adjustment is a key strategy for optimizing efficacy and safety. This can be achieved by integrating pharmacogenomics models to precisely calculate individualized dosing regimens. The theoretical basis for this strategy stems from the significant amplification of functional differences in the OGG1 Ser326Cys polymorphism under specific tumor microenvironment stresses. For example, the antiangiogenic drug bevacizumab inhibits the VEGF signaling pathway, reducing tumor angiogenesis and leading to hypoxia in the tumor microenvironment. Hypoxia can induce oxidative stress, significantly increasing levels of ROS and NO [ 109 110 P 111 112 113 Dynamic dose adjustment based on OGG1 genotype is critical—pharmacogenomics models can be used to precisely calculate individualized dosing. Bevacizumab reduces tumor angiogenesis by inhibiting the VEGF pathway, leading to hypoxia in the tumor microenvironment and inducing oxidative stress, resulting in elevated ROS/NO levels [ 109 P 110 111 5 The integration of OGG1 gene polymorphism and environmental factors contributes to disease prevention and risk assessment. Oxidative DNA damage can be caused by ROS, and environmental factors such as smoking and environmental pollution may increase oxidative stress, which in turn affects the function of the OGG1 gene. Understanding the interactions between OGG1 gene polymorphisms and environmental factors can lead to early intervention and prevention in high-risk populations [ 6 Outlook and discussion The OGG1 Ser326Cys polymorphism and human diseases have multiple associations. It plays an important role in complex diseases such as cancer, neurodegenerative diseases, and diabetes by affecting dynamic repair mechanisms. This review integrates multiomics data with molecular mechanism studies to reveal the multidimensional role of this polymorphism in genomic stability and disease susceptibility, and explores its translational potential in precision medicine. Molecular mechanisms of OGG1 functional defects and disease susceptibility OGG1 forms the Ser326Cys polymorphism due to the frequent Substitution of Ser by Cys at position 1245 in exon 7. Its central pathological effect stems from significant differences in its enzymatic activity, leading to impaired repair kinetics, especially under oxidative stress, where its 8-oxoG excision activity is reduced by about sevenfold compared to the Ser326 type [ 4 14 Disease association: environmental interactions and racial heterogeneity Currently, there is no specific explanation for the difference in increasing cancer risk between Asian and Caucasian populations for OGG1 polymorphisms, which now tends to support that it is due to differences in dietary environment. However, the existing evidence is highly concentrated in Asian and Caucasian populations, and the conclusions may not apply to individuals of other ancestral backgrounds (such as those of African descent). In CRC, Cys326 type leads to 8-oxoG accumulation due to repair defects, driving chronic inflammation and malignant transformation. The risk of cancer is 1.56-fold higher in Asian populations with the GG genotype compared to the CC type, which may be associated with the interaction of genetic background and environmental exposures (smoking, red meat intake) [ 6 31 114 115 116 117 Of the various lifestyle factors, smoking may provide the strongest environment for the generation of oxygen free radicals. A series of studies have shown that smokers have increased oxidative DNA damage compared to non-smokers. There is a significant association in lung cancer, but the current findings suggest that oxygen radicals produced by tobacco smoke may be associated with colon carcinogenesis, although the role may be limited [ 31 118 There was a statistically significant interaction between OGG1 polymorphisms and dietary intake of vegetables, with a 54% reduction in lung cancer risk for every 50% increase in vegetable intake in Cys-only carriers, and no reduction in risk in Ser326 carriers. The same trend was seen for fruit intake in Ser or Ser326Cys. However, current research focuses on data and lacks a specific mechanism by which vegetables and fruits reduce the risk of disease. OGG1 as a therapeutic target: small-molecule activators Given the role of OGG1 functional defects (such as those associated with the Ser326Cys polymorphism) in the pathogenesis of various diseases, strategies to enhance its repair activity hold potential therapeutic value. In recent years, the discovery of small-molecule compounds that can specifically activate OGG1 has brought new hope to this field. These activators are designed to improve OGG1’s efficiency in recognizing and excising 8-oxoG. For example, Benitéz-Buelga et al. synthesized two small-molecule activators, TH12117 and TH10785, for use as organic catalysts. TH12117, as an organic catalyst, mimics the excised 8-oxoG, replacing the excised base and interacting with the same amino acid residue. It initiates a β-elimination event, releasing the Lys249 residue and enabling OGG1 to begin a new catalytic cycle [ 11 100 This discovery not only demonstrates the feasibility of pharmacologically regulating OGG1 activity but, more importantly, reveals a previously unknown pathway for enhancing DNA base excision repair [ 100 119 These findings support the use of small-molecule OGG1 activators as a potential strategy to compensate for reduced repair capacity caused by OGG1 gene polymorphisms, thereby potentially reducing the risk of related diseases or slowing their progression. Notably, small-molecule OGG1 activators enhanced the activity of the functionally impaired OGG1 Ser326Cys variant associated with Alzheimer’s disease and all-cause mortality [ 32 120 Although this field holds great promise, the development of OGG1 activators remains in its early stages. Future research must thoroughly explore their in vivo efficacy, specificity, long-term safety, and therapeutic effects in different genetic backgrounds (such as carriers of Ser326Cys or other OGG1 variants). In-depth investigation of these issues will determine the feasibility of translating such strategies into clinical interventions. Limitations of existing research and future directions There are several key limitations to current research: (1) Most epidemiologic studies have not controlled for epigenetic confounders (such as age of DNA methylation), (2) lack of validation in large-scale cohorts across ethnicities, with a serious dearth of data from African populations in particular, (3) uncertainty as to the role of OGG1 polymorphisms in disease progression and how they may specifically affect disease treatment. Future research needs to break through three key directions: (1) Analyze the genetic background of the Ser326Cys polymorphism in different ethnic populations. (2) Clarify the mapping of the polymorphism's regulation of disease phenotypes through DNA methylation, histone modification, and non-coding RNA networks. (3) Develop precise genotype-based interventional strategies, including the design of Cys326-type specific activators to restore the phosphorylation function, or the use of HDAC inhibitors to enhance the sensitivity of OGG1-deficient cells to chemotherapy. In addition, for autoimmune diseases and CVDs with few current studies, it provides a new perspective to expand the disease association spectrum. In conclusion, in-depth study of OGG1 gene polymorphisms, as a core node connecting genetic susceptibility, molecular repair mechanisms, and environmental exposure, will provide a solid scientific foundation for the integrated “prevention–diagnosis–treatment” strategy in precision medicine. Conclusion The Ser326Cys polymorphism in the OGG1 gene, a key genetic variant in the DNA oxidative damage repair pathway, systematically destabilizes the genome by decreasing 8-oxoG excision efficiency. At the molecular-functional level, this polymorphism not only directly impairs the 8-oxoG excision activity of OGG1, but also significantly affects its subcellular distribution dynamics-Ser326-type OGG1 is retained longer in the insoluble fraction of the nucleus and is more accurately localized to the nucleolus in the S phase through phosphorylation-mediated localization, whereas the Cys326 type has a reduced efficiency of repair site recruitment due to impaired phosphorylation [ 14 16 28 In terms of disease association, the Ser326Cys polymorphism is a key genetic regulatory hub for complex diseases such as cancer, neurodegenerative diseases, metabolic syndrome, and reproductive disorders through a multidimensional molecular mechanism that significantly affects the ability to repair oxidative damage, and exhibits significant disease susceptibility differences and racial heterogeneity. In the field of cancer, this polymorphism has become an important risk factor for various malignant tumors such as lung, breast, and CRC through the triple mechanism of “defective repair-accumulation of oxidative damage-epigenetic reprogramming”: In Asian populations, the risk of cancer is 1.56-fold higher in the GG homozygous genotype (Cys/Cys) compared with the CC wild-type (Ser/Ser), especially in gastrointestinal and upper respiratory tract cancers, the risk of the pure genotype model reaches 1.36-fold and 1.74-fold, respectively [ 6 39 45 In neurodegenerative diseases, defective OGG1 function accelerates the disease process through the mechanism of “oxidative damage-insufficient repair-repetitive sequence amplification.” In HD model, Cys326 type leads to the accumulation of 8-oxoG in neurons, which induces the somatic amplification of CAG repeat sequences, thus advancing the onset of the disease; in metabolic diseases Such as type 2 diabetes mellitus, due to the insufficient repair of oxidative stress in β-cells, the function of insulin secretion of Cys326 type is reduced by 25–30% compared with that of wild-type. The HOMA-IR insulin resistance index was significantly elevated, and the risk of disease was increased in those with homozygous genotypes [ 8 32 In the field of translational medicine, OGG1 polymorphisms have demonstrated dual potential as biomarkers: They can be used as early screening indicators for cancer, such as the positive correlation between GGG1 transcription levels and Cys allele dosage in peripheral blood mononuclear cells of lung cancer patients, and also predict chemotherapy resistance; for example, in NSCLC, patients with CG genotype have a median progression-free Survival of only 6 months, which is 3 months shorter than those with CC genotype [ 37 41 101 Publisher's Note Springer Nature remains neutral with regard to jurisdictional claims in published maps and institutional affiliations.
